operation.instruction: Replacing a word/phrase by a synonymous word/phrase, in the appropriate context, results in a paraphrase of the original sentence/phrase. This category covers the special case of genitives, where the clitic ’s is replaced by other genitive indicators like of, of the, and so forth. This category also covers near-synonymy that is, it allows for changes in evaluation, connotation, and so on, of words or phrases between paraphrases.

operation.instruction: Changing the function words in a sentence/phrase without affecting its semantics, in the appropriate context, results in a paraphrase of the original sentence/phrase. operation.instruction: Replacing a word/phrase denoting an action, event, and so forth, by a word/phrase denoting its possible future effect, in the appropriate context, results in a paraphrase of the original sentence/phrase. This may be accompanied by the addition/deletion of appropriate function words and sentence restructuring. This often generates a quasi-paraphrase.

example_list.source: Google is in talks to buy YouTube.
example_list.target: Google bought YouTube.

example_list.source: The Marines are fighting the terrorists.
example_list.target: The Marines are eliminating the terrorists.

task_list.original: He worked hard on the presentation, and his colleagues appreciated it, but he felt he could improve.
task_list.paraphrase: He worked hard on the presentation, and his colleagues appreciated it, but possibilities for enhancement remained.

task_list.original: If you heat water, it boils.
task_list.paraphrase: If you heat water, steam is produced.

task_list.original: Because the teacher explained the concept, all the students understood.
task_list.paraphrase: Because the teacher explained the concept, the topic was comprehended.

task_list.original: The teacher is explaining the concept to students.
task_list.paraphrase: The teacher will enhance the students' understanding.

task_list.original: As he read the letter, his face showed surprise.
task_list.paraphrase: As he read the letter, emotions were stirred.

task_list.paraphrase: The author will expand their literary contributions.

task_list.original: He turned on the light, and everyone could see.

task_list.paraphrase: The artist will beautify the public space.

task_list.paraphrase: She studied all night, so she was tired in the morning, but she succeeded in the test.

task_list.paraphrase: They will improve traffic flow across the river.

task_list.paraphrase: The scientist will contribute to eradicating the disease.

task_list.original: The city is repairing the damaged roads.
task_list.paraphrase: The city will improve road safety and comfort.

task_list.original: She opened the window, and a breeze filled the room.
task_list.paraphrase: She opened the window, and air circulated in the room.

operation.instruction: Replacing a numerical expression (a word/phrase denoting a number, often with a unit) by an approximately equivalent numerical expression (even perhaps with change of unit), in the appropriate context, results in a paraphrase of the original sentence/phrase. This often generates a quasi-paraphrase.

example_list.source: At least 23 U.S. soldiers were killed in Iraq last month.
example_list.target: About 25 U.S. soldiers were killed in Iraq last month.
Disneyland is around 30 minutes from here.

task_list.original: The car can go 200 kilometers on a full tank, and the tank can hold 60 liters.
task_list.paraphrase: The car can go about 125 miles on a full tank, and the tank can hold 60 liters.

task_list.paraphrase: When the cake bakes for about half an hour, it becomes perfectly fluffy.

task_list.original: The park is 2 kilometers away.
task_list.paraphrase: The park is about 1.2 miles away.

task_list.original: The building is 50 feet tall, and it was constructed in 1998.

task_list.original: The recipe needs 2 liters of water.
task_list.paraphrase: The recipe requires roughly half a gallon of water.

task_list.original: The concert held 500 people, and the tickets sold out in one day.
task_list.paraphrase: The concert held around 500 people, and the tickets sold out in about 24 hours.

task_list.paraphrase: Because he trains for about half an hour daily, he is very fit.

operation.instruction: Replacing a word/phrase by another word/phrase based on extra-linguistic (world) knowledge, in the appropriate context, results in a paraphrase of the original sentence/phrase. This may be accompanied by the addition/deletion of appropriate function words and sentence restructuring. This often generates a quasi-paraphrase, although in some cases preserves meaning exactly.

example_list.source: We must work hard to win this election.
example_list.target: The Democrats must work hard to win this election.

example_list.source: The government declared victory in Iraq.
example_list.target: Bush declared victory in Iraq.
